text: A myope’s far point is 25 cm in front of the cornea. What single-vision spectacle power (at the cornea) neutralizes distance blur?
rationale: F = −1/l = −1/0.25 m = −4.00 D (at the principal plane).

text: Hyperopia is most accurately described as:
choices: The far point is a virtual point behind the eye
The far point lies in front of the eye
Light focuses on the retina without accommodation
Corneal power is always too steep
rationale: In hyperopia, parallel light would focus behind the retina; the far point is virtual and posterior.

text: An axial length increase of ~1.0 mm changes refractive error by approximately:
rationale: Rule of thumb: ≈ 2.5 D per mm around the 24-mm eye.

text: A −3.00 D myope looking at 33 cm without correction requires how much accommodation?
rationale: Object demand at 33 cm is 3.00 D; the myope’s far point provides a “head start,” so no additional accommodation is needed.

text: Uncorrected hyperopes at optical infinity must:
rationale: Distance clarity requires accommodation to overcome latent/manifest hyperopia.

text: The spherical equivalent (SE) of −2.50 −1.50 × 180 is:
With-the-rule corneal astigmatism typically shows the steepest curvature:
rationale: WTR = steeper vertically; correcting axis near 180°.

text: The circle of least confusion (CLoC) is located:
choices: Midway between the two focal lines
At the retina in all astigmats
rationale: CLoC lies at the midpoint of the interval of Sturm and corresponds to the spherical equivalent focus.

text: A patient’s habitual Rx is −10.00 D in spectacles worn at 15 mm. What is the approximate contact-lens power (at the cornea)?
rationale: Fglasses = FCL/(1 − d·FCL) → solving backward gives ≈ −9.00 D for the contact lens.

text: Reducing vertex distance for high minus spectacles generally:
choices: Has no effect on effective power
rationale: Bringing a minus lens closer decreases its effective negative power and minification.

text: Presbyopic near add is commonly estimated with:
rationale: Book formula for balanced comfort near work.

text: Which procedure most directly flattens the central cornea to correct myopia?
rationale: Excimer ablation reduces central corneal curvature to decrease power.

text: Conductive keratoplasty (CK) is primarily used for:
rationale: Peripheral collagen shrinkage steepens the center—useful for low hyperopia; regression can occur.

text: SMILE differs from LASIK mainly by:
choices: Creating/removing a lenticule without a flap
Adding a flap and no lenticule
rationale: SMILE removes a corneal lenticule via small incision; flapless.

text: Refractive lens exchange for presbyopia/hyperopia trades improved focus for which drawback?
choices: Higher corneal edema risk than LASIK
No effect on depth of field
rationale: Removing the crystalline lens eliminates natural accommodation.

text: Best definition of anisometropia:
choices: Significant inter-ocular difference in refractive power
Different K readings with same SE
rationale: Clinically relevant size or power differences can disrupt fusion and induce aniseikonia.

text: Aniseikonia greater than ~5–7% often leads to:
rationale: Size disparity above tolerance causes discomfort, distortions, and loss of fusion.

text: According to Knapp’s law, which correction minimizes image-size difference in axial anisometropia?
choices: Spectacles at the anterior focal plane
rationale: For axial anisometropia, spectacle lenses placed at the principal plane reduce aniseikonia vs. contacts.

text: For refractive anisometropia, which correction tends to minimize aniseikonia?
choices: Any correction yields the same size
rationale: Refractive anisometropes usually experience less size difference with CLs.

text: A patient is −8.00 D OD and −2.00 D OS in spectacles at 12 mm. Which statement is true about spectacle magnification?
choices: OD image is more minified than OS
OS image is more minified than OD
Spectacle minification is independent of power
rationale: Higher minus power produces greater spectacle minification at a given vertex distance.

text: Which change most effectively reduces spectacle minification in a high myope?
rationale: Decreasing vertex distance reduces effective minus power and minification.

text: The interval of Sturm is defined as the distance between:
choices: The two line foci in astigmatism
The anterior focal line and retina
The posterior focal line and retina
rationale: Astigmatic systems create two perpendicular line foci.

text: Oblique astigmatism correction often causes which initial patient complaint?
choices: Binocular diplopia in primary gaze only
rationale: Meridional magnification changes can make planes appear tilted until adaptation occurs.

text: You refract −2.00 −2.00 × 180 to 20/20. What single-vision SE would place the CLoC on the retina?
A patient’s amplitude of accommodation is 4.00 D. For 40-cm work, a comfortable add by the (Demand − AA)/2 rule is:
rationale: Demand at 40 cm = 2.50 D; (2.50 − 4.00) is negative so the minimal + add for comfort ≈ +1.00 D (clinical rounding).

text: Compared with spectacles, high myopes wearing contact lenses typically experience:
choices: Less minification and wider field of view
rationale: Eliminating vertex distance reduces effective minus and increases field of view.

text: A +3.00 D hyperope fitted with contact lenses will, compared with spectacles, experience:
rationale: Moving plus power from spectacle plane to the cornea reduces spectacle magnification.

text: Spherical equivalent is most useful clinically to:
choices: Place the CLoC on the retina for initial trial lenses
rationale: SE helps center the blur distribution when full cylinder is being fine-tuned.

text: A −6.00 D spectacle lens at 12 mm is switched to 0 mm (contact lens). The contact lens power will be:
rationale: Minus lens moved closer loses effective minus power; convert using Fcl ≈ Fsp / (1 + d·Fsp).

text: Which is TRUE about axial vs refractive myopia?
choices: Axial myopia increases risk of retinal detachment more than purely refractive myopia
Refractive myopia is always due to lens changes
Axial myopia has a virtual far point
Refractive myopia results from a short eye
rationale: Axial elongation stretches the retina and is linked with higher detachment risk.

text: Which single change most increases spectacle magnification for a given plus Rx?
rationale: Magnification rises with increased shape factor (base curve/thickness).

text: A plano −2.00 × 090 cylinder lens produces focal lines oriented:
choices: Horizontal and vertical, with the more minus power at 180°
At the circle of least confusion only
rationale: Minus cylinder adds power 90° from its axis—here, most minus at 180° (horizontal meridian).

text: Immediately after prescribing first-time high cylinder, which counseling point is MOST appropriate?
choices: Temporary tilt/warp sensation that improves with adaptation
Permanent distortion that requires Rx reduction
Color shift due to chromatic aberration
rationale: Meridional magnification can make floors/walls look tilted; most patients adapt.

text: A 50-year-old with 2.00 D of hyperopia has an AA of 2.00 D. Approximate add at 40 cm for comfort is:
rationale: Distance correction removes the hyperopic burden; near demand 2.50 D with 2.00 D AA → add about +2.25 D (clinical rounding).

text: For a high hyperope in spectacles, moving the lens closer to the eye generally:
choices: Induces base-in prism in primary gaze
Has no effect on field of view
rationale: Reducing vertex distance lowers effective plus power and reduces magnification.

text: A patient has −5.00 −1.00 × 180. Which change best reduces perceived horizontal line tilt on first-wear?
choices: Slightly reduce cylinder while maintaining SE initially
rationale: Small cyl reduction (with SE preserved) can ease meridional magnification symptoms during adaptation.

text: Which statement about presbyopic depth of field is TRUE after cataract surgery (monofocal IOL)?
choices: Patients rely more on depth of field since accommodation is lost
Depth of field decreases to zero
Near vision becomes independent of pupil size
rationale: Loss of accommodation makes patients depend on depth of field; smaller pupils help at the cost of diffraction.

text: Which best describes the far point for a +2.00 D uncorrected hyperope?
choices: A virtual point 0.5 m behind the cornea
A real point 0.5 m in front of the cornea
A real point 2.0 m behind the cornea
rationale: F = +2.00 D corresponds to a virtual far point at −0.5 m (posterior to the eye).

text: The most appropriate first-line correction to minimize aniseikonia in a refractive anisometrope (−8.00 D OD, −1.00 D OS) is:
choices: High-index spectacles with higher base curve OD
rationale: Contacts reduce vertex-related size differences compared with spectacles.

text: In simple myopic astigmatism, the retinal image at best focus is:
choices: A line focus with one focal line on the retina
A point image on the retina
Two point images equidistant from the retina
rationale: One focal line falls on the retina while the other lies in front of it.

text: Primary optical change in LASIK for myopia is to:
rationale: Central flattening reduces system power so parallel rays focus on the retina.

text: A −5.00 D myope is over-minused by 1.00 D in trial frame at distance. What happens to accommodation demand for distance targets?
choices: They must accommodate about 1.00 D for distance
rationale: Over-minus effectively makes the patient hyperopic by 1.00 D for distance, requiring accommodation.

text: Which is MOST consistent with symptomatic latent hyperopia in a young adult?
choices: Sudden painless monocular blur and cherry-red spot
rationale: Cycloplegia unmasks the full hyperopic error and relieves accommodative spasm symptoms.
